newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sour crudes retain strength in late trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sour crudes retain strength in late trade.

text.p: U.S. sour crudes retained their strength in late cash trading on Wednesday, traders said.
One Gulf Coast buyer attributed part of the firmness on Mexican and Venezuelan moves to store sour crude in the Caribbean, but this could not be immediately confirmed.
The continued closure of Mexico's Pajaritos port could be another factor, traders said.
May West Texas Intermediate was trading around $19.30-40 a barrel, down 25 cents from late Tuesday, on bearish stock data released by the American Petroleum Institute (API) on Tuesday.
West Texas Sour/Midland was around $2.00-1.95 a barrel under WTI/Cushing, with $2.00 last changing hands, up 10-15 cents from Tuesday.
Eugene Island was talked at WTI/Cushing minus $1.95-85 barrel after moving at minus $2.00 earlier.
Sweet grades were steady to weaker as the market digested a wave of West African crude on the Gulf Coast.
Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James was at minus 40-35 cents, while Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire was at minus $1.00 to 90 cents. HLS was last done at minus 95 and minus $1.00.
WTI/Cushing Posting Plus was pegged at $1.81-83 a barrel.
